bibl.title: [Letter] 1838 Aug. 30, Rurel Rest [to] James King, Rutherford County, Murfreesboro, Tennessee / Henry King
bibl.author: King, Henry
bibl.note: This is a letter dated August 30, 1838 from Henry King to his father James King. In the letter Henry tells his father of his endeavors at the market, as well as the prices per pound that he obtained for his hams.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 3.0 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.opener:
Family Letters__ Col James M King Murfrees Bouugh Borough Rutherford County Tennessee Thomas KingAnn parrishWm Parrish } ? miscellaneous calculations Tuscaloosa AL Aug 31 Letter from Henary a. j. King. 1838 25
Your Benevolent Sun Henry A. J. King James M King
Rurel Rest Augt 30 1838 Dear Father
div1.p:
After a travil of twenty days Maj Woods and myself with the wagons reached Tuskalosa. I arived at Cousin William Parishes finding all well except cousin Ann she has bin sick near all the summer She now walks about the house. . he Cousin William & cousin Ann sayes thay would be verry glad to see you all. We hv hired as sell and unloaded too wagons Bruckman. & Lewis and sent them back to day Maj Woods with his wagon persued for father markett and left me hear to Sellu out U what is hear. this morning I sold thirty nine hams waying 5.49 lb. at 15 cts the others I sold on the road at 14 & 15 which a wer the best prices theair wer thre spoilt hams the people commonly like the necked ham better than the canvas Maj Woods sayes if he sells ou that he cured down below first he wlil wil take the remainder to the best market. u Mj. Woods wrot to you at Dittoes Landing in which letter I expect you have received in which he states of altering the rout and going to words Georgiae from inquiries and informations we concluded to take the first rout towards Tuskaloosaand Sumpter County I hav not yet seen cousin Thomas King yet I understan that he is complaining. Tell my relations and friends that I am in tolerable health & Maj. Wood Cousin Millia Parishes family is well except cousin Ann Tuskaloue Agst 30 1838
miscellaneous calculations
